subject: Re: [junit] Combining JUnit and Ant

messageBody:
I typically use a build.xml that declares a JUnit task for the main test
suite and a parameterized JUnit task to run any single test case. The
main test suite is run as a dependent of rebuilding or distributing the
software. The single test cases are run as often as necessary, though I
prefer to reuse an active JUnit window when refactoring.

An example build.xml snippet follows:


<!--
Main Test Suite
-->
<target name="test" if="junit.present" depends="compile.tests"
description="Runs the JUnit test cases">

<junit printsummary="no" haltonfailure="yes">
<classpath>
<path refid="project.classpath" />
<pathelement path="${classes.dir}" />
</classpath>
<formatter type="plain" usefile="false" />
<test name="${main.test.case}" />
</junit>

</target>

<!--
Test Case

Use: ant -Dtestcase=com.whatever.TestCaseName test.case
-->
<target name="test.case" if="testcase" depends="compile.tests"
description="Runs the specified JUnit test case">

<junit printsummary="no" haltonfailure="yes">
<classpath>
<path refid="project.classpath" />
<pathelement path="${classes.dir}" />
</classpath>
<formatter type="plain" usefile="false" />
<test name="${testcase}" />
</junit>

</target>

Mike

Robert Leftwich wrote:

> I have just made the switch to using Ant to build my system and have
> incorporated the optional JUnit task and it is brilliant (not only JUnit
> but Ant as well). My question is one of usage in the development cycle -
> how are people using the ant/junit combination in actual development,
> particularly in a test first, XP -style of development where you tend to
> work in a single package while making changes or adding new functionality
> and as a consequence want to run the tests for that package (or more often
> a single TestCase) after the build. Are you adding a junit task to the
> build file for each TestCase (which could easily get out of hand), or
> perhaps for each package (and wearing the slower test time) or do you not
> even use ant/junit at this level, instead keeping a junit (ui or cli)
> window open and run the tests from there after a successful build ?
>
> TIA
>
> Robert
